Ian, this is definitely an interesting topic.  In the Hayek system, is
there a difference between training and testing?  The way you
described it, it sounds like it i always training, so there is always
a chance of a mutant making a bid.  Or does the probability go down
for some reason?  I guess I should go read the paper... 

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> Hi,
> 	I'm a newby here but I've been lurking a few weeks.
> 
> 	This multiple networks topic is pretty much at the heart of my 
> interests.  I'm not coming only from an ANN angle, but I'm very
interested 
> in approaches for combining multiple entities of any
evolving/learning type 
> (ANN, GP, GA, ...) into coherent wholes.
> 
> 	It's a complex area and not hugely reported in the existing literature.
> 
> 	I've found two existing approaches exist:
> 
> 1) those variations on the "classifier system" approach which use the 
> output form the whole population.  Typically this seems to be
achieved by 
> letting the fittest individual process all those cases it can before 
> passing any remaining cases to the next fittest.  Obviously for 
> classification you can do this because the discrete "cases" are
separate 
> and can be seen to be handled or not.  This is harder to apply to other 
> scenarios (hence your need for "confidence").  It's also necessary
to be 
> able to assess an individual in the absence of the others, which
also may 
> not apply for a complex situation.
> 
> 2) The "Hayek" approach of Eric Baum 
> (http://www.whatisthought.com/eric.html).  This uses economics to
control 
> the confidence in each individual.  Individuals in each tick,
analyse the 
> situation and bid an amount of money to be the dominant controller
(Eric 
> phrases this "bidding to own the world").  The winner pays its bid
to the 
> previous successful bidder ("buying the world form the previous owner", 
> which may be itself) and then takes control for one tick.  Any
improvement 
> in the value of the world after the individual's actions are
credited to 
> it, as well as the money from the individual buying control in the
next tick.
> 
> This system works because it forces individuals to evolve an accurate 
> measure of their own confidence.  Any individual which overbids will
make a 
> loss, go bankrupt and be killed.  Any which underbids will never get 
> control, make no profit, and the systems often include a fixed or 
> size-related "tax" which in time bankrupts these individuals as well.
> 
> --
> 
> I'm cautiously keen on the Hayek approach, although it has at least one 
> pretty serious weakness: in a generation, a mutant high-bidding
individual 
> can grab control and deflect the whole system from profitability
(say by 
> ramming a boulder head-on).  Existing Hayek implementations handle this 
> because any runs in which the system as a whole is unprofitable are
taken 
> back and the offending individual eliminated (or to put it another way, 
> deals involving individuals who "default" on their bids are unwound
back to 
> a previous state).  This is a fine strategy as long as the world 
> (simulation) the system lives in is cheap (because it has to be
unwound as 
> well) but impractical for (i) complex simulations, (ii) simulations 
> inhabited by more than one Hayek system, or (iii) physically
implemented 
> worlds (like real motorbikes in real deserts, for example).
> 
> But you can easily imagine using Hayek in this situation, feeding money 
> into the system for either forwards motion or reaching the end
(either has 
> been seen to work).  Giving each ANN an output for bid (confidence) in 
> addition to its control outputs.  And there would be no concerns
with using 
> several different types of ANN in the population...
> 
> 	Ian Badcoe
> 
> 
> 
> Living@Home - Open Source Evolving Organisms - 
> http://livingathome.sourceforge.net/
